document.text: Valuable publicity for Appo mattox has been the result of featur ed material in the current issue of Transgas, the splendid monthly magazine of Transcontinental Gas Pipe Line Corporation, with principal offices in Houston, Texas. Ken B. Harper is editor of Transgas. He was in Appomattox recently and gathered pictures and material for the article which will advertise Appomattox over a vast area of Eastern Ameri ca served by Transcontinental. The magazine has high rating as an in dustrial publication. The front cover of the current is sue pictures Otis P. Dewberry, Supt. adjusting one of the big valves on the gas-cooler at Transcos Station 17 at Appomattox. The back cover of the magazine shows the residence of Mrs. F. C. Dresser inAppomattox. Subject of the featured material is,  88 Years Later, referring to the fact that Appomattox is thriving 88 years after the peace made in 1865. The inside front cover shows a full page picture of the McLean House. The historical story begins on Page 5, with a full page drawing of Lee and Grant shaking hands in re- concialation. There follows a well- written account of. the events of the April, 1865 peace-making. Page 8 comes up with a full page of Editor Calvin Robinson in his office at the Times-Virginian .plant, There follow many pages about the operations of Transcontinental in Appomattox and commentary on the thriving economy of the modern community 88 Years Later. Pictures include Engineer Lloyd Bryant at a spotless auxiliary unit a scene of Transco housing at Dewberry Hill  the Patteson - Hix Tavern Farmers National Bank and Bank of Appomax, Mauds Hot Shop, the Bocock - Isbell House Appomattox Garment Co., Inc. R. L. McIntyre runnning a chemical test at Station 17 the New Appomattox Court House A. G. Thompson and Hanley Phelps on a mechanical job at Station 17 5 a view of the Confed erate Cemetery Billy Pettet, radio technician at Station 17 Robert M. Honeycutt, foreman of Crew 3, PL. Dist. 7 and a two-page panoramic picture of Station 17 itself. The read ing material features interviews on modern Appomattox, with W. W. Burke, T. DeWitt Evans, R. B. A Cavalry Company was formed under the command of Capt. Joel W. Flood, becoming Co. H of the 2nd Va. Cavalry. A Company of Heavy Artillery was formed under Capt. James Robertson. A Company of Infantry under Capt. Thos. P. Mat thews, and another Company was formed under Capt. Wm. H. Abbitt, and quite a number of Appomattox citizens living near the rim of the county joined companies from adjoining coun ties. With hearts aflame and bodies dedicated to the Cause they held dear, they went to the front and shared the destiny of the heroes in Gray. Weakened by casualties, new calls came for volunteers, and long after the war, there was a scarcity of able bodied men in the County. Then came April 9, 1865, and the hand of destiny wrote finis across the scroll of four mighty years of struggle Destiny selected Appomattox for one of the major events oi history. Today there is hardly a town- or village in America, that has not heard of Appomattox. Thus ended in this Coun ty, one of the greatest Civil Wars ever chronicled in the files of Time, and at Appomattox began a new page in the history of America. Military rule was established shortly after April 9, 1865. Al county officers were replaced by military appointees. These were men who were selected upon the recommendation of the incumbents, and were willing to take the Iron Clad Oath. In the fall of 1866, an election was held under the Under wood Constitution, which put into effect the 13th and 14th Amendments to the Constitution of the United States, and a new slate of officers were named. Geo. T. Peers became Clerk Wm. T. Johnson Sheriff W. J. Collins, Commissioner of the Revenue the Office of County Treasurer was created Supervisors were provided for, and the ounty Government, practically as we have it now was estab lished. The ravages of four years of war were apparent, and Ap pomattox along with her sister counties, began to repair the wounds. The following years called forth the character and ability of her people, and the present institutions of our Coun- -y are but a tribute to their untiring labor and foresight. document.text: political life. Now as to the social side of his life, you must see that it was fa mous, considering the political life he led. He was no only a most wel come guest, but a most desired one on all occasions, and was perfectly at ease in any gathering, a kind neighbor, and staunch friend, a lover of and beloved by mankind. No un welcome guest ever approached his doorstep. Whoever same, high or low, rich or poor, received a hearty welcome. Mr. Bocock took great pleasure in helping others, and one act he was justly proud of was securing the appointment of General Jeb. Stuart t o West Point. General Stuarts by his brilliant achievement during the War, ranked as one of the greatest cavalry generals of all time. In his later years, when old age began to weigh heavily on him, and that once brilliant light of genius and intellect began to grow dim, that other light which had nut failed bo shine through his life, the light of morality and faith in his God grew brighter, and guided him on the day set by his God for the An gels of Heaven to hover around to bear that noble spirit to the God who gave it. Thus, on the 5 th day of August, 1891, on the farm on which he was born, among the friends and his family he loved so well and who loved him so dearly, Thomas Salem Bocock passed to his glorious re ward.

document.text: Mrs. Martha A. Gills, a for mer resident of Appomattox, died at the home of her daugh ter, Mrs. T. L. Payne, in Crewe, April 11. Mrs. Gills was 93 years of age. She was a daugh ter of the late Captain Wilson Hix, of Appomattox, a leader in the community which play ed so dramatic a part in the War Between the States. Her mother was a sister of Hon. Thomas S. Bocock, of Appo mattox, who was the speaker of the House during the brief re gime of the Confederacy. Mrs. Gills remembered vivid ly the circumstances of the sur render of General Lee at Appo mattox. The surrender took place on a farm owned by her rather, and the terms of sur render were drawn and signed in a building formerly owned by her father, who sold it to Major McLean during the war. General Grant took possession of her fathers home for eight days while the Confederate sol diers were being paroled. When the Union soldiers were beginning to evacuate the village, an officer approached the young daughter of the house and informed her that he had hidden away a barrel of flour and a chicken, so that when they were gone her fami ly might not suffer for provi sions. The gloom of war was bright ened for Mrs. Gills by the ro mantic attachment she felt for her first cousin, Daniel Gills, a young cavalrymen in Fitzhughjj Lees brigade, which after the war culminated in marriage. document.text: Mrs. IJooocks House Burned. The entire village was startled by the alarm of fire on last Friday. It was soon learned that the alarm was due to the fact that the beauti ful residence of Mrs. Annie H. Bo- cock was on fire. A large crowd soon assembled at the burning build ing ready to do all in their power to save it or its contents, but the fire had gotton too much headway. Only one room could be entered, but for tunately this was the library, which contained the splendid miscellaneous library, one of the best in State collected by the late Hon. Tlios. S. Bocock. The entire library and most of the furniture in the room were saved, but nothing else. The loss to Mrs. Bocock was very heavy. The house was insured, but of course to only three-fourths of  its value, while there was no insur ance at all on the furniture. Mi3. Bococks furniture was veiy handsome, some of it coming from Boydville, the ancestral home of Mrs. Bocock. The alarm was given at 230 p. m. and in twenty five minutes the house was in ashes. Our people deeply sympathize with Mrs, Bocock in her great loss.
